Without this key, when the transition from the old FAB to the new one starts, the two FABs get mixed up. The old one seems to end up with the new one's performance, until the new one grows in.

comments.body: this is fine. I'd even add an assert that bottomSheetKey.currentState isn't null.

There don't seem top be any uses of ScaffoldFeatureController.setState() except for the hack I added (and will remove).  However: I suppose the idea is that someone who's only holding on to the feature controller can update some state that the feature controller depends inside of myFeatureController.setState().

That's what I've done; it does work. It's not as tidy as just calling setState() once, on the application itself.

I kind of wanted to use EdgeDims.zero here because the name says to avoid (all) window padding, but things go badly if you skip the top padding here.

Maybe we should rename it to resizeToAvoidBottomPadding?
Although consider if Android were to use bottom padding to keep us out of the soft buttons. Presumably the padding would be non-zero without a keyboard, and merely bigger with a keyboard. So really it's about not responding to padding changes? I don't really know what the right solution is here but I feel like what we're doing right now isn't fully coherent.

comments.body: are you sure this is the right order? why was it above the bottom sheets before but not now?
please add a test that verifies that we're getting the right z-order when you have all these widgets present

Well, according to the spec, snack bars should be below bottom navigation and bottom sheets should be above bottom navigation. There wasn't any rule for snack bars and bottom sheets per se, but you can infer the order now that bottom navigation is in the equation.
This would be the place to explain how the bottom navigation bar is laid out vis the scaffold's bottom sheet and its snackbar.
Fixed.

I suppose you could also check for `config.persistentFooterButtons.length > 0`. On the other hand, maybe it's better to have the substructure in place for the inevitable rebuild with a non-empty buttons list.
Yeah, I figured it would be better to treat an empty list by drawing the bar and leaving a null list as the way to get rid of the bar.
I might say something about "upward" here.  For example: "No Scaffold ancestor could be found starting from the context that ..."
(Will fix in subsequent patch, since moving a branch to another development machine is a pain.)
Agree re: indicating a direction in which we looked :)

Mostly interested in the rationale for the existing behaviour. Though probably good to deal with that in a followup patch when we've got the changes to BottomNavigationBar etc. to support the iPhone X.
I didn't really examine what the existing behaviour actually was. :-) Scaffold could probably do with a round of cleanup, it's accumulated cruft over the years.

comments.body: make this required?
Done.

@Hixie @HansMuller 

Please take a look at this change.  We discussed it separately, but brief recap:


> What's happening is that the top, end and bottom of mediaQuery.padding are all getting passed to the scaffold layout
But with start-aligned fabs, we really need the start padding as well
and so at this point it's easier to just pass the padding directly and find the start and end padding in the relevant positioner
It would be helpful to briefly explain what a typical use case for ScaffoldGeometry is.
Done.
am I missing something or is this animation always going to say 1.0?

A "floatingActionButton" property should hold a floating action button.
I agree that "position" suggests an Offset.

This gives you the area that the FAB would cover if it was not scaled, right?
Maybe "floatingActionButtonArea"?
done
This should probably mention that only the last call will be remembered, so if there's two FloatingActionButtons, only one will be represented in the ScaffoldGeometry.
Added. Though it feels a bit over-verbose to mention that a setX method overrides the previous value of X...
Add BottomAppBar to the list of "See also"s for Scaffold around line 500.
done
Are they really points between host.topLeft and host.topRight?

For the generic notch we don't need to require that they are necessarily within the host bounds. 
For the fab notch we have some extra guarantees that are described in the doc for setFloatingActionButtonNotch.
It says `the start and end offsets ... will always be on the top edge of [bottomNavigationBar]` (that should imply they are between host.topLeft and host.topRight, happy to also explicitly say that there if you think it clarifies).
This would be a good place to also explain what start and end are for.
They are explained 2 paragraphs below, did you mean to change the paragraph order?
Should we say something like "It will typically be a Material"?
some comments as above
nit: mention the accessible behavior in the method's Dartdoc.

Missing unit test for this scenario (hideCurrentSnackbar is called with/without accessibleNavigation).
Should be L522-523 of snack_bar_test.dart to cover the true case, other case is handled previously
right missed that.

When the user turns off accessibility while the snackbar is showing we will get some inconsistent behavior - the time the snackbar will remain visible will be somewhat random between 0 to snackBar.duration.

What do you think about listening to the accessibility change again and then firing a timer?

It's not inconsistent, it's just undefined in the snackbar spec.

It's not a common use case to toggle TalkBack on and off while showing snackbars. This simplifies the implementation so we don't have to add/remove listeners on window.

I think that from the user's perspective it's inconsistent: you turn off accessibility and the snack bar might disappear immediately or after a few seconds.

But I agree it's not a very important edge case so ok to avoid complicating the code for that.
i don't think a periodic timer is a good idea here. we'd be waking the CPU regularly while accessibility is enabled, even though nothing is happening.
please at a very minimum leave a TODO here saying that this will hurt battery for accessibility users.

I've update this to use the didChangeDependencies lifecycle to close the snackbar if a11y is disabled - https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/lib/src/material/scaffold.dart#L1407.

Shouldn't have a significant effect on the battery?
I think we've stopped giving local constants like this a `_k` prefix.
Should really explain what it's based on (appbar preferred height plus the top padding)

A "see also" section that pointed at https://docs.flutter.io/flutter/material/ScaffoldState/openDrawer.html would be helpful.

The openDrawer() doc should similarly "see also" isDrawerOpen.
The `[ScaffoldState.openDrawer]` will automatically generate a link to https://docs.flutter.io/flutter/material/ScaffoldState/openDrawer.html, so you can remove the explicit link here and below.

comments.body: i wonder if this is really correct in all cases...

The value of `minInsets.bottom` is just the media query's value of  viewInsets.bottom (unless resizeToAvoidBottomInsets is false). It doesn't guarantee that the keyboard is up however if someone were to configure a MediaQuery that way we'd react the same was as if the keyboard is up.

I think this is OK, albeit complicated: we don't extend the bottom of the body if resizeToAvoidBottomInsets is true (the default) and viewInsets.bottom is non-zero.
Same comment about a line break between the first sentence and the rest.
